factoid: The Rostóvs knew everybody in Moscow.
The old Count Ilyá Rostóv had enough money that year.
All of the old Count Ilyá Rostóv's estates had been remortgaged.
Nicholas Rostóv acquired a trotter of his own.
Nicholas Rostóv had very stylish riding breeches of the latest cut.
No one else in Moscow had riding breeches of that latest cut before Nicholas Rostóv.
Nicholas Rostóv had boots of the latest fashion with extremely pointed toes.
Nicholas Rostóv had small silver spurs on his boots.
Nicholas Rostóv passed his time very gaily.
After a short period of adapting, Nicholas Rostóv found it very pleasant to be at home again.
Nicholas Rostóv felt he had grown up and matured very much.
Nicholas Rostóv had despair at failing in a Scripture examination.
Nicholas Rostóv borrowed money from Gavríl to pay a sleigh driver.
Nicholas Rostóv kissed Sónya on the sly.
Nicholas Rostóv recalled these events as childishness he had left immeasurably behind.
Nicholas Rostóv was a lieutenant of hussars.
Nicholas Rostóv wore a jacket laced with silver.
Nicholas Rostóv wore the Cross of St. George.
The Cross of St. George is awarded to soldiers for bravery in action.
Nicholas Rostóv trained a trotter of his own for a race in the company of well-known, elderly, and respected racing men.
Nicholas Rostóv knew a lady on one of the boulevards whom he visited in the evening.
Nicholas Rostóv led the mazurka at the Arkhárov's ball.
Nicholas Rostóv talked about the war with Field Marshal Kámenski.
Nicholas Rostóv visited the English Club.
Nicholas Rostóv was on intimate terms with a colonel of forty to whom Denísov had introduced him.
Nicholas Rostóv's passion for the Emperor had cooled somewhat in Moscow.
Nicholas Rostóv did not see the Emperor.
Nicholas Rostóv had no opportunity of seeing the Emperor.
Nicholas Rostóv often spoke about the Emperor and about Nicholas Rostóv's love for the Emperor.
Nicholas Rostóv let it be understood that Nicholas Rostóv had not told all.
Nicholas Rostóv believed there was something in Nicholas Rostóv's feelings for the Emperor that not everyone could understand.
Nicholas Rostóv shared the adoration then common in Moscow for the Emperor.
The Emperor was spoken of as the “angel incarnate.”
During Nicholas Rostóv's short stay in Moscow, before rejoining the army, Nicholas Rostóv did not draw closer to Sónya.
During Nicholas Rostóv's stay in Moscow, Nicholas Rostóv drifted away from Sónya.
Sónya was very pretty and sweet.
Sónya was evidently deeply in love with Nicholas Rostóv.
Nicholas Rostóv was at the period of youth when there seems so much to do that there is no time for that sort of thing.
Nicholas Rostóv feared to bind himself and prized his freedom.
Nicholas Rostóv needed freedom for many other things.
When Nicholas Rostóv thought of Sónya, Nicholas Rostóv said to himself: “Ah, there will be, and there are, many more such girls somewhere whom I do not yet know.”
Nicholas Rostóv said there will be time enough to think about love when Nicholas Rostóv wants to.
Nicholas Rostóv had no time to think about love now.
Nicholas Rostóv thought the society of women was rather derogatory to his manhood.
Nicholas Rostóv went to balls and into ladies’ society with an affectation of doing so against his will.
Nicholas Rostóv participated in races, the English Club, sprees with Denísov, and visits to a certain house.
These activities were a matter and quite the thing for a dashing young hussar.
At the beginning of March, old Count Ilyá Rostóv was very busy arranging a dinner in honor of Prince Bagratión at the English Club.

The count walked up and down the hall in his dressing gown, giving orders to the club steward and to the famous Feoktíst, the club’s head cook, about asparagus, fresh cucumbers, strawberries, veal, and fish for the dinner.
The count had been a member and on the committee of the club from the day it was founded.
The club entrusted the arrangement of the festival in honor of Prince Bagratión to the count.
Few men knew how to arrange a feast on an open-handed, hospitable scale.
Fewer men would be so well able and willing to make up out of their own resources what might be needed for the success of the fete.
The club cook and the steward listened to the count’s orders with pleased faces.
They knew that under no other management could they so easily extract a good profit for themselves from a dinner costing several thousand rubles.
The count said: “Well then, mind and have cocks’ comb in the turtle soup, you know!”
The cook asked: “Shall we have three cold dishes then?”
The count considered.
The count said: “We can’t have less—yes, three... the mayonnaise, that’s one.”
The steward asked: “Then am I to order those large sterlets?”
